subject: Test method names, 2
msgSnippet: ... AHA! AHA AHA AHA! That s it! Why is it always the case that someone else says perfectly what I m trying to say poorly? It is not important whether method X
messageBody:
> >The basic question is, "When you have multiple test methods that test
> >a single method, what naming convention do you use for the test
> >methods?"
>
>We concentrate more on testing behavior of a class rather than testing each
>method explicitly. Below are methods from one of our tests. These all are
>testing the create() method on a factory class. Notice how we aren't
>really
>concerned about the method name, but more about behavior.
>
> public void testBuiltIns() throws Exception {
> public void testDupsAreBad() throws Exception {
> public void testNoSimpleType() throws Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeNoDefault() throws Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeDefaultString() throws
>Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeDefaultStringBaseUnknown()
>throws Exception {
> public void testUnsupportedSimpleTypeNoDefaultList() throws
>Exception {

AHA! AHA AHA AHA! That's it!

Why is it always the case that someone else says perfectly what I'm trying
to say poorly?

It is not important whether method X does XYZ unless there is a feature that
method supports. So test the feature, not the method. If, after you test all
the features, you find that method X supports none of them, then kindly kill
method X.

JBR.
